3.5.6. National Urban Regeneration 
Programme
With the gradual transition of 
intervention policies in Deprived urban 
areas from a “physical renewal” model 
to an “urban regeneration” approach, 
the evolution of approaches and 
methods of action was also prioritised 
by policymakers. This transformation 
redefined the scale of intervention from 
macro-level and physically-oriented 
towards small-scale, thematic, and 
neighbourhood needs-based actions. 
Urban regeneration policy emphasises 
the linkage of physical dimensions 
with social, economic, cultural, and 
institutional considerations, pursuing it through comprehensive, participatory, 
and multi-sectoral programmes.
A turning point in this shift of 
approach was the approval of the 
“National Strategic Document for the 
Revitalisation, Upgrading, Revitalisation, 
and Empowerment of Deteriorated and 
Deprived Urban Areas” in 2014. This 
document defined interdisciplinary 
and integrated objectives across three 
dimensions: physical-spatial, socio-
cultural, and economic-environmental, 
and placed the enhancement of 
urban quality of life in target areas, in 
conjunction with other urban spheres, 
at the centre of attention.
Subsequently, Article 59 of the Sixth 
National Development Plan Law (2017–
2021) mandated the government to 
implement regeneration programmes 
in at least 270 target neighbourhoods 
annually across the country. Following 
this, the “National Sustainable Urban 
Regeneration Taskforce” was approved 
and communicated to provincial 
and county taskforces, aiming to 
fulfil the quantitative requirements 
of this law. This programme, relying 
on the framework of the National 
Regeneration Policy and supporting 
legal documents, has become one of 
the most comprehensive and organised

field of regeneration and enhancing the 
quality of life in cities.
At the scale of target neighbourhoods, 
this programme pursues four key 
missions:
1. Enhancing the quality of public 
spaces and neighbourhood 
infrastructure.
2. Developing and equipping 
superstructure and social services.
3. Upgrading, revitalising, and 
retrofitting residential units.
4. Empowering residents socially, 
economically, and institutionally.
- Institutional Structure and 
Implementation Process:
The implementation process of 
the National Sustainable Urban 
Regeneration Taskforce is inter-
sectoral, multi-stage, and participatory,

member agencies.
The Secretariat of the National 
Taskforce, the Iran Urban Regeneration

and coordinating role, is responsible

• Allocation of credits from the annual

through active participation in plan 
preparation, issuance of construction 
permits, and provision of public services.

actions pertain to the creation and 
strengthening of public and social 
service centres such as cultural centres, 
neighbourhood houses, sports halls, 
educational centres, clinics, libraries,

stations.
The aim of these actions is to increase 
access for low-income groups residing 
in Deprived areas to public services, 
strengthen social capital, enhance 
the sense of belonging, and improve 
urban liveability at the neighbourhood 
level. The approach to developing 
superstructure services, beyond addressing physical needs, seeks to 
enhance human and social capacities 
and create equal opportunities for the 
growth and flourishing of residents in 
regeneration target neighbourhoods.

2024, a total of 1,168 projects 
in the field of developing and 
equipping superstructure services 
and infrastructure have been 
implemented in urban regeneration 
target neighbourhoods across the 
country. These actions have included 
the construction of libraries, cultural 
spaces, neighbourhood houses, sports 
facilities, parks, urban spaces, and 
service centres; actions that have not 
only led to the enhancement of the 
physical functions of neighbourhoods 
but have also provided a suitable 
platform for empowering local 
communities and enhancing social 
cohesion.

participatory regeneration process in

Social and economic empowerment is a 
purposeful process wherein individuals, 
groups, and local communities, 
by enhancing their capacities, are 
enabled to gain greater control over 
various aspects of their individual and 
collective lives and play an active role 
in the local development process. This 
empowerment is pursued through three 
axes: institution-building, capacity-
building, and tool development:
• Institution-building  refers to the 
formation and strengthening of local 
social and civil institutions, aimed at 
enhancing social capital, attracting 
public participation, and increasing 
community involvement in urban 
planning and management processes.
• Capacity-building , by providing 
educational opportunities, developing 
skills, and enhancing social and civic 
awareness, creates the foundation for 
meaningful resident participation in 
improving their quality of life.
• Tool development  refers to the 
creation of financial, legal, and 
regulatory frameworks to facilitate 
and expedite the urban regeneration process, achieved through identifying 
obstacles and providing specific 
solutions such as formulating bylaws, 
reforming laws, designing incentives, 
and granting loans.
Alongside these axes, a series of non-
physical and promotional programmes  
are envisaged to sustain and deepen 
the effectiveness of actions, including:
• Networking:  Aimed at creating 
synergy and preventing duplication 
of effort, through the formation 
of networks and self-help groups, 
strengthening inter-sectoral 
cooperation, and utilising diverse 
participatory tools among various 
stakeholders.
• Mainstreaming:  Aimed at shaping a 
public discourse and demand among 
citizens, through education, promotion, 
information dissemination, organising 
cultural and specialised events, 
and producing practical resources 
and documents to enhance public 
awareness.
• Institutionalisation:  Aimed 
at consolidating and sustaining 
programmes through documentation, 
establishing databases, continuous 
monitoring and evaluation of actions, 
knowledge management, and reforming 
planning and implementation structures

Lessons Learned134Lessons Learned
Over the past two decades, the process 
of urban upgrading and revitalization in 
Iran has followed a transformative and 
evolutionary path. This path has shifted 
from scattered, project-based, and 
predominantly physical interventions 
towards integrated management, 
program-based approaches, and the 
strengthening of participatory methods. 
The formation of the institutional 
structure for this process began with 
the establishment of the Iran Urban 
Development and Improvement 
Corporation in 1997. Subsequently, a 
series of studies and research in the 
late 1990s, as well as collaboration with 
the World Bank in the early 2000s in the 
field of urban upgrading, significantly 
contributed to consolidating the 
theoretical and conceptual framework 
of this domain.One of the significant achievements 
of this period was the approval of 
the “National Empowerment and 
Regularization Document for Informal 
Settlements” in 2003. This document, 
inspired by the fundamental principles 
of the first UN-Habitat (United Nations 
Human Settlements Programme) 
declaration (Vancouver Declaration 
on Human Settlements, 1976), is 
considered a turning point in Iranian 
urban policymaking. For the first time, 
the civil rights of the inhabitants of 
these settlements, including security of 
tenure, and their social rights, such as 
access to basic services, were officially 
recognized. This document also 
provided the necessary institutional 
and policy framework for the effective 
participation of residents and their 
interaction with the government, paving 

Sustainable Urban Regeneration in I.R. IRAN135the way for a shift in perspective 
towards informal settlements from an 
“insoluble urban problem” to an “urban 
issue with potential.”
The devastating Bam earthquake in 
2003 further highlighted the importance 
of urban renewal and urban seismic 
retrofitting. Consequently, the Fourth 
National Development Plan (2004–
2008) mandated the government to 
undertake revitalization, retrofitting, and 
the preparation of a Comprehensive 
Housing Plan with an approach 
centered on sustainable development, 
social justice, and the empowerment 
of low-income groups. Furthermore, 
the resolution by the Supreme Council 
of Urban Planning and Architecture of 
Iran, defining indicators for identifying 
areas in need of revitalization and 
upgrading – including instability, fine-
grain texture, and impermeability (lack 
of access) – provided the necessary 
legal dimensions for intervention in 
these areas. As a result, within less 
than eight years, approximately 76,000 
hectares of deteriorated urban areas 
were identified.However, the lack of distinction 
between different types of deprived 
urban neighborhoods and the 
absence of differentiated programs 
severely diminished the effectiveness 
of interventions. This challenge 
necessitated a revision of approaches, 
eventually leading to the replacement 
of revitalization policy with urban 
regeneration policy. This policy shift 
was formalized with the approval of 
the “National Strategic Document 
for the Revitalisation, Upgrading, 
Revitalization, and Empowerment of 
Deteriorated and Deprived Urban Areas” 
in 2014. This document, by adopting 
a comprehensive, multidimensional, 
and context-sensitive approach to 
different types of areas, is considered 
an effective step towards improving 
the quality of life for residents and 
enhancing the efficiency of urban 
interventions.
The shift in approach from large-
scale, physically-oriented interventions 
to small-scale, community-based 
actions was institutionalized through 
the experience of sustainable urban 

Lessons Learned136regeneration policy. The conceptual 
transition from “shelter” to “housing,” 
from “inhabitant” to “citizen,” and from 
“settlement” to “neighborhood” was 
solidified in Iranian urban development 
literature through the implementation 
of a decade of sustainable urban 
regeneration policy. Policies, programs, 
and actions were shaped and evolved 
under this conceptual transition.
The preparation of three national 
strategic documents over three 
decades, each playing an evolutionary 
theoretical and procedural role relative 
to the previous one; the establishment 
of regeneration taskforces; and the 
transition from physically-oriented 
indicators to livability and city-
wide indicators in the identification, 
revitalization, and upgrading process 
(at the policy level); the formulation 
of the National Regeneration Program 
and the elevation of urban revitalization 
and upgrading to a national issue 
within the framework of the Sixth 
National Development Plan (at the 
planning level); and the experience 
of establishing and operating local development institutions and 
implementing the Joint Comprehensive 
Plan of Action in both thematic and 
area-based categories (at the action 
level), were all tools for improving urban 
quality of life under the umbrella of 
sustainable urban regeneration in Iran.
The shift in approach from large-scale, 
physically-oriented interventions to 
small-scale, community-based actions 
was institutionalized in Iran through 
the implementation of sustainable 
urban regeneration policy. This 
transformation provided a platform for 
a conceptual transition from “shelter” to 
“adequate housing,” from “inhabitant” 
to “citizen,” and from “settlement” to 
“neighborhood.” These transitions, over 
a decade of implementing this policy, 
have become established in Iranian 
urban development literature and have 
shaped the conceptual and operational 
framework of policies, programs, and 
actions.

national strategic documents in 
three consecutive decades—each 

Sustainable Urban Regeneration in I.R. IRAN137representing an evolutionary step in 
theoretical and operational dimensions 
compared to its predecessor—
have played a decisive role. The 
establishment of “Sustainable Urban 
Regeneration Taskforce” at national, 
provincial, and local levels, and the 
shift from purely physical indicators 
to “livability indicators” and “inclusive” 
urban indicators in the process of 
identification, revitalization, and 
upgrading, signify a transformation at 
the policy level.
At the planning level, the formulation 
of the “National Urban Regeneration 
Program” and the transformation of 
urban regeneration into a “national 
issue” within the framework of the Sixth 
National Development Plan have been 
important steps in institutionalizing this 
approach in macro-development plans.
At the action level, the experience 
of establishing and operating “local 
development institutions” and 
implementing the “Joint Comprehensive 
Plan of Action” in both thematic and 
area-based categories demonstrates an 
effort to combine institutional, social, and physical capacities with the aim of 
improving urban quality of life within 
the framework of sustainable urban 
regeneration.
Despite challenges in the process of 
implementation, institution-building, 
inter-sectoral coordination, and 
resource mobilization, sustainable 
urban regeneration policy in Iran has 
generally shown a progressive trend 
and has managed to establish its 
position within Iran’s urban planning 
and development system. This 
experience, particularly in terms of 
institution-building, strengthening local 
participation, enhancing the role of local 
communities in decision-making, and 
giving simultaneous attention to social, 
economic, physical, and environmental 
dimensions in programs and actions, 
has high potential for transfer to other 
countries facing similar conditions.
In conclusion, it can be said that 
sustainable urban regeneration policy 
in Iran has not only created a discursive 
shift in the perception of deprived urban 
areas but has also been able to lay 
the foundations for multi-level action, 

Lessons Learned138integrated planning, and participatory 
policymaking. Based on this experience, 
some of the most important extractable 
lessons learned are:
• Integrated Management and 
Program Cohesion:  Effective 
advancement of regeneration programs 
requires integrated management 
at various levels and inter-sectoral 
coordination in policy formulation and 
implementation. This is achieved when 
regeneration programs and actions are 
directly linked to comprehensive spatial 
and urban development documents, 
and a departure is made from 
uncoordinated sectoral and project-
based approaches.
• Attention to the Diversity of Deprived 
Area Types:  Success in regeneration 
necessitates a precise understanding 
of the diversity among deprived urban 
areas, including deteriorated, historic, 
and informal settlements. Adopting 
differentiated approaches tailored to 
the characteristics of each type of 
these areas significantly increases the 
effectiveness and efficiency of policies 
and executive actions.
• Contextualized and Inclusive Social 
Policy:  Iran’s experience shows that 
social policies must be formulated in a way that they are both inclusive of 
different societal strata and appropriate 
to the socio-economic characteristics 
of each region. The focus of these 
policies on strengthening the family 
institution through the provision of 
services such as education, health, 
housing, insurance, and social support 
plays a fundamental role in enhancing 
urban resilience and social justice.
• Housing and Urban Development 
Affordable for Low-Income Groups: 
Reforming urban planning orientations 
and formulating regulations appropriate 
to the economic capacity and living 
conditions of low-income groups 
are prerequisites for success in 
regeneration. Achieving this goal 
requires a review of the housing and 
urban planning policymaking system.
• Gradual Upgrading:  Effective 
regeneration is based on the gradual, 
step-by-step improvement of the 
quality of life in the neighborhood. 
This process will be successful when 
intervention measures are designed 
and implemented not from top-down 
but based on the capacities, assets, and 
participation of the residents.
• Voluntary and Safe Resettlement 
in the Face of Hazards:  When dealing 
with areas exposed to natural or 

Sustainable Urban Regeneration in I.R. IRAN139man-made hazards, the principle of 
resettlement must be accompanied 
by full respect for human rights, active 
participation of residents, ensuring 
social satisfaction, and guaranteeing 
suitable housing replacement. 
Successful implementation of this 
principle requires effective dialogue and 
fair compensation mechanisms.
• Strengthening Local Management 
and Decentralization:  Increasing 
the authority and capacity of local 
institutions, including municipalities 
and local bodies, plays a pivotal role 
in achieving regeneration. Utilizing 
participatory mechanisms, capacity 
building for civil society organizations, 
and enhancing the link between people 
and decision-making institutions 
are key factors for success in local 
regeneration management.
• Targeted Support for Vulnerable 
Groups:  Policymaking in deprived areas will not be effective without 
identifying and providing special 
support to vulnerable groups, 
especially female-headed households, 
children, the elderly, and persons with 
disabilities. Designing empowerment 
and social support programs tailored 
to the conditions of these groups is a 
necessity for equity-oriented planning.
• Mobilizing Endogenous Resources 
with External Convergence:  Advancing 
sustainable regeneration policy 
requires the optimal aggregation of 
local, governmental, public, community, 
and private resources. Appropriate 
institution-building and the use of 
innovative financial and institutional 
tools can provide the platform for the 
effective use of neighborhoods’ internal 
capacities and create synergy with 
external resources.

Lessons Learned140Glossary of Terms
Urban Regeneration: The process 
of comprehensive development in 
economic, social, environmental and 
physical terms aimed at enhancing 
the quality of life bacross target urban 
areas and neighborhoods in connection 
with the rest of the city.
Target Urban Areas and 
Neighborhoods: Areas that are 
the subject of regularization plans of 
this Document based on approved 
initiatives for their revitalization, 
rehabilitation and renovation.
Deprived urban areas: These 
are areas within the city that require 
Revitalisation, upgrading, and 
revitalization. They are categorized 
into types such as historic areas, 
deteriorated areas, and informal 
settlements. The prominent 
characteristics of these areas are as 
follows:
• Residents have lower per capita 
incomes and higher unemployment 
rates as compared with the city 
averages.
• As compared with the city averages, 
housing units are not durable, 
population density is high, and there are also environmental problems.
• Residents have inadequate access to 
urban services and infrastructure.
• As compared with the rest of the city, 
social aberrations are apparent and 
further encouraged.
• Historic and cultural identities have 
been neglected—social dignity and 
social esteem have declined in these 
areas—giving rise to an underclass 
substitution effect
Deteriorated urban area:  Refers 
to areas within a city where, over past 
years, constituent elements—including 
superstructures, infrastructure, 
buildings, structures, streets, and 
access ways—have become dilapidated 
and inefficient, and whose residents 
suffer from multiple economic, social, 
cultural, and physical problems.
Historic Urban Areas:  Section(s) of 
city reflecting cultural-historic values, 
formed through the interaction between 
human beings and their surrounding 
environments in the course of time 
and distinguished from other zones 
by apparent characteristics and 
constituent structures.
Informal settlement:  Areas 

Sustainable Urban Regeneration in I.R. IRAN141predominantly inhabited by rural 
migrants and the urban poor, which 
have developed without legal permits 
and outside of formal and legal urban 
development planning (such as 
comprehensive and detailed plans), 
either within or outside the legal 
boundaries of cities.
Empowerment:  The expansion of 
residents’ assets and capabilities with 
the aim of enhancing their own quality 
of life and enabling their participation 
in the regularization and development 
process.
Foresight and Prevention: Refers 
to a set of systematic policies, 
programmes, and actions within various 
spatial, social, land, and housing 
development frameworks, aimed at 
preventing the formation and growth of 
informal settlements.
Regularization: Regenerating target 
urban areas and neighborhoods 
through reanimation, revitalization, 
rehabilitation and renovation that 
enable residents and enhance the 
quality of their lives and activities in the 
settlements.
Renovation:  The holistic process in 
economic, socio-cultural and physical 
terms, aimed at restoring proper living conditions based on new relations 
and establishing a dynamic balance in 
target urban areas and neighborhoods.
Revitalization: The purposive 
process comprising a set of measures 
aimed at protecting and enhancing 
the quality of target zones and 
neighborhoods while preserving their 
authenticity and integrity.
Urban upgrading: Is a multi-sectoral 
approach to improving the physical, 
social, economic and environmental 
conditions of deprived urban areas, 
especially informal settlements and 
slums, through the provision of basic 
services, infrastructure, housing 
improvements, and institutional

foreword
 with an urban heritage spanning several millennia  iran ranks among the world s 
foundational civilizations in the evolution of human settlements  from prehistoric 
communities to historic cities such as isfahan  yazd  and tabriz  iranian urban structure 
has consistently reflected the integration of humanity  nature  culture  and art  during 
the islamic periods  principles of communal life  neighborhood integration  and vibrant 
public spaces were further reinforced  today  emerging concepts of sustainability  
spatial equity  and resilience are being reconsidered through an ongoing global 
exchange of expertise 
the frameworks for urban planning in iran were first established in the early twentieth 
century with the municipal law  over time  successive institutions including the supreme 
council of architecture and urban planning and the sustainable urban regeneration 
taskforce have evolved into an inclusive  multi tiered framework that promotes 
collaboration and coordination across all levels of governance and stakeholders 
today  with over    percent of the population living in cities  iran faces both challenges 
and opportunities  uneven development  housing crisis  natural hazards  and climate 
change have compelled policymakers to review established development models  
nevertheless  urban planning experience in iran demonstrates institutional adaptability  
resilience  and a capacity for learning  qualities that have recently given rise to innovative 
planning policies 
within this context  the national housing movement aims to provide four million 
housing units  by utilizing local capacities and social capital  the movement seeks 
to enhance housing affordability by eliminating land cost barriers  creating various 
financing mechanisms  and utilizing the technical and operational expertise of non 

x
governmental organizations to bridge the gap between actual housing needs and 
access to safe  affordable  and dignified housing 
simultaneously  the spatial development strategy in the country is transitioning 
from unregulated sprawl to targeted infill development  through the revitalization of 
deteriorated urban areas  enhancement of existing infrastructure  and improvement of 
public transportation  we are striving to establish an endogenous  sustainable urban 
form 
current strategic urban planning embodies a commitment to enhancing livability and 
inclusiveness for all  including children  seniors  and people with disabilities  the 
supreme council s adoption of child friendly city guidelines and accessibility standards 
for persons with disabilities demonstrates a responsive approach to designing safe  
inclusive  and adaptive urban environments  the shift from conventional unproductive 
methods to problem driven  participatory frameworks showcases our transformative 
approach to urban planning 
urban regeneration viewed as a favorable strategy for addressing current challenges  
with a focus on endogenous development and  public participation  the goalies to 
create more livable and inclusive cities  drawing upon its traditional and institutional 
capacities  the islamic republic of iran sees active participation in implementing the 
new urban agenda as a national duty

foreword
       with the transformation of the global economy and the accelerating pace of 
urbanization  a convergence of positive and negative phenomena has emerged  these 
phenomena impact not only national economies but also profoundly influence living 
conditions across urban areas  particularly in developing countries 
 one of the most pressing challenges is the declining quality of the physical and 
social fabric of urban settlements  along with the increasing urbanization of poverty  
unequal access to decent jobs  adequate housing  resilient basic services  and the 
systemic marginalization of social minorities have all contributed to physical and 
spatial fragmentation  these factors have led to the emergence of urban and peri 
urban zones facing multidimensional poverty  these areas are expanding rapidly due 
to being overlooked in formal planning systems 
in iran  additional stressors such as prolonged drought  migration driven by regional 
political crises in neighboring countries  and economic sanctions have further 
accelerated the formation and growth of unsustainable urban areas and deteriorated 
urban areas  despite these formidable constraints  urban regeneration efforts have 
persisted  with the annual production of more than half a million housing units over the 
past two decades 
we are firmly committed to the belief that addressing these interconnected challenges 
and achieving sustainable  inclusive  and balanced urban development  requires the 
optimal utilization of infill development capacities and the active participation of 
citizens   especially those  residing in deprived urban districts 
according to national policy documents  deprived urban areas in iran are classified 
into three main categories  informal settlements  deteriorated urban areas  and historic 
centers  while these areas differ in their origins and structural characteristics  they are 
united by shared indicators of poverty albeit with varying dimensions and intensity  with 

xii
nearly one third of the country s urban population residing in such areas  revitalization 
has been prioritized across several legislative and strategic platforms 
notably  in the past two decades  the government has developed and adopted 
three national policy frameworks focused on empowerment  upgrading  and urban 
regeneration  urban poverty is multi functional with various related components  and 
multiple stakeholders involved in policy making  decision making  and implementation  
therefore  it is essential to have a comprehensive perspective  integrate decisions  and 
coordinate programs and actions among all relevant stakeholders 
in response  iran established the sustainable urban regeneration taskforce  surt  in 
      as a structured  cross sectoral governance mechanism operating at all levels  
national  sub national  and local  this initiative aims to harmonize policies  coordinate 
actions  mobilize financial and institutional resources  and provide integrated 
stakeholder management to address all forms of urban decay 
by enhancing urban resilience  improving quality of life  and putting marginalized urban 
areas on a path toward inclusive growth  we aim to empower residents to take active 
roles in the urban development process  our goal is to overcome physical fragmentation 
as well as social and economic exclusion in our cities 
we strongly believe that alongside proactive and preventive policies  endogenous 
development  rooted in the capabilities and assets of local communities  must 
be actively pursued  this can only be achieved through capacity building  asset 
enhancement  participatory  demand responsive approaches  and the mobilization of 
public  private  and civil society resources 
indeed  the realization of urban prosperity for all hinges on equitable access to and 
enjoyment of our cities and human settlements  this vision will only be realized when we 
ensure that all residents across generations can live in cities free from discrimination  
creating inclusive  safe  affordable  resilient  and sustainable human settlements 
requires commitment to the principles and implementation of the new urban agenda  
it is essential to remember that progress toward the sustainable development goals 
must be grounded in both our historical legacy and the sharing of contemporary 
experiences  both nationally and internationally

     in an era of rapid urbanization  where the urban population currently exceeds

preface
the emergence and persistence of deprived urban areas reflect the inefficiencies of 
sectoral and spatial development planning  historical experience demonstrates that 
this phenomenon was an unavoidable aspect of early industrialization  even in today s 
advanced nations      the primary cause lay in the absence of the requisite technical 
knowledge  institutional capital  and financial resources for sustainable policymaking  
however  the continuation and expansion of these zones over time signify a dual 
failure  that of the market  market failure  and of policy  policy failure       market 
failure manifests as the inability of pricing mechanisms to equitably allocate resources 
 such as land and housing  to low income groups  while policy failure stems from 
inefficient institutions  contradictory laws  and a lack of integrated planning      these 
twin failures culminate in spatial dysfunctions  such as spatial poverty traps  of which 
informal settlements are the most prominent contemporary manifestation 
informal settlements  as one type of deprived urban area  refer to a collection of human 
habitations formed outside the formal urban planning and management system  
according to the united nations human settlements programme  un habitat   these 
settlements are typically characterized by a lack of security of tenure  insufficient 
access to basic urban services  high population density  and substandard housing 
quality  this phenomenon  depending on its formative context  manifests in various 
forms within urban areas  ranging from historic and deteriorated areas to informal 
settlements 
the evolution of global attention to the sustainability of human settlements can be traced 
through three pivotal habitat conferences  the first habitat conference in vancouver  
canada  in       centered on  adequate shelter for all   marked the initial step in 
formally recognizing this issue at an international level  two decades later  habitat ii 
in istanbul  turkey  in       adopted a more comprehensive approach by emphasizing 

xxvii
the  sustainable development of human settlements   the watershed moment in 
this progression was habitat iii in quito  ecuador  in       which  with the adoption 
of the  new urban agenda   presented an innovative framework for confronting 
urban challenges  this document  by underscoring citizen rights and community 
based approaches  instigated a fundamental paradigm shift in the perception of 
these settlements  globally  the adoption of the sustainable development goals 
 sdgs  in       particularly goal    which focuses on  making cities and human 
settlements inclusive  safe  resilient and sustainable   had a historically significant 
concurrence with the developments of habitat iii  specifically  target      of this 
goal concentrates on  ensuring access for all to adequate  safe and affordable 
housing and basic services and upgrade slums   this temporal convergence signals 
the global community s resolve to adopt an integrated approach to addressing the 
challenge of informal settlements 
the study of deprived urban areas in theoretical literature reveals a significant 
conceptual evolution  from an initial perspective that viewed these settlements 
merely as an urban  problem       we have now moved towards a paradigm that 
considers them part of the solution to urban issues     
this conceptual transformation of deprived urban areas in global literature  from 
a uni dimensional  problem focused view to a holistic  solution oriented approach  
has profoundly influenced urban policymaking in iran  while in the early decades 
     s     s   the dominant approach was based on physical demolition and 
clearance of these settlements  recent decades have witnessed a fundamental 
shift towards integrated and empowering strategies  the world bank s intervention 
in the form of an upgrading loan in the     s was a turning point in this evolution  
although its initial aim was the physical improvement of settlements  in practice  
it led to a change in policymakers  attitudes  a strengthening of community 
based approaches  and the creation of new institutional frameworks  the urban 
regeneration approach  which gained traction globally almost concurrently with the 
new urban agenda  represents a fundamental change in iran s urban policymaking  
transcending the uni dimensional and physically oriented perspectives of 
the past  this approach is founded on three core principles  integrated vision 
 amalgamating physical  social  economic  and environmental dimensions   
participation  actively engaging local stakeholders   and institution building 
 developing sustainable management structures  

xxviii
sustainable urban regeneration policy in iran encompasses a diverse range of urban 
areas  which can generally be termed  deprived urban areas   including historic 
areas  deteriorated areas  and informal settlements  despite sharing common 
characteristics such as poverty  limited access to services and infrastructure  
and high population density  these areas exhibit significant differences in terms 
of their formation  tenure status  and other contextual dimensions  consequently  
intervention programs and actions within them must be designed and implemented 
in a manner that is attuned to these distinctions 
iran s experience in implementing sustainable urban regeneration policy 
demonstrates that this approach  by fostering inter sectoral coordination and 
leveraging local capacities  has taken effective strides towards improving deprived 
urban areas  the significance of the urban regeneration approach in iran can be 
summarized in several key aspects 
 firstly  this approach has transcended ad hoc  project based strategies to become 
a sustainable  process oriented policy 
 secondly  by forging links between different planning levels  from national to local   
it has enabled the coordination of various actions 
 thirdly  by recognizing the role of local communities  it has harnessed the internal 
capacities of these settlements as an effective factor in the development process  
these characteristics have transformed urban regeneration into an efficient model 
for addressing the challenge of informal settlements in iran 
iran s experience in urban regeneration  despite numerous challenges  highlights 
the significant potential of sustainability principles and approaches for enhancing 
the quality of life in cities  this experience can offer valuable lessons for many 
developing countries facing similar challenges  however  the continuation and 
deepening of this approach necessitate constant attention to its various dimensions 
and the continuous updating of policies in light of global transformations and 
national experiences

over the past two decades  the process 
of urban upgrading and revitalization in 
iran has followed a transformative and 
evolutionary path  this path has shifted 
from scattered  project based  and 
predominantly physical interventions 
towards integrated management  
program based approaches  and the 
strengthening of participatory methods  
the formation of the institutional 
structure for this process began with 
the establishment of the iran urban 
development and improvement 
corporation in       subsequently  a 
series of studies and research in the 
late     s  as well as collaboration with 
the world bank in the early     s in the 
field of urban upgrading  significantly 
contributed to consolidating the 
theoretical and conceptual framework 
of this domain one of the significant achievements 
of this period was the approval of 
the  national empowerment and 
regularization document for informal 
settlements  in       this document  
inspired by the fundamental principles 
of the first un habitat  united nations 
human settlements programme  
declaration  vancouver declaration 
on human settlements         is 
considered a turning point in iranian 
urban policymaking  for the first time  
the civil rights of the inhabitants of 
these settlements  including security of 
tenure  and their social rights  such as 
access to basic services  were officially 
recognized  this document also 
provided the necessary institutional 
and policy framework for the effective 
participation of residents and their 
interaction with the government  paving

towards informal settlements from an 
 insoluble urban problem  to an  urban 
issue with potential

of urban renewal and urban seismic

national development plan       
      mandated the government to 
undertake revitalization  retrofitting  and 
the preparation of a comprehensive 
housing plan with an approach 
centered on sustainable development  
social justice  and the empowerment 
of low income groups  furthermore  
the resolution by the supreme council 
of urban planning and architecture of 
iran  defining indicators for identifying 
areas in need of revitalization and

grain texture  and impermeability  lack

in       this document  by adopting

transition from  shelter  to  housing   
from  inhabitant  to  citizen   and from 
 settlement  to  neighborhood  was 
solidified in iranian urban development 
literature through the implementation 
of a decade of sustainable urban 
regeneration policy  policies  programs  
and actions were shaped and evolved 
under this conceptual transition 
the preparation of three national 
strategic documents over three 
decades  each playing an evolutionary 
theoretical and procedural role relative 
to the previous one  the establishment 
of regeneration taskforces  and the 
transition from physically oriented 
indicators to livability and city 
wide indicators in the identification  
revitalization  and upgrading process 
 at the policy level   the formulation 
of the national regeneration program 
and the elevation of urban revitalization 
and upgrading to a national issue 
within the framework of the sixth

implementing the joint comprehensive

level   were all tools for improving urban 
quality of life under the umbrella of 
sustainable urban regeneration in iran 
the shift in approach from large scale  
physically oriented interventions to 
small scale  community based actions 
was institutionalized in iran through 
the implementation of sustainable 
urban regeneration policy  this 
transformation provided a platform for 
a conceptual transition from  shelter  to 
 adequate housing   from  inhabitant  
to  citizen   and from  settlement  to 
 neighborhood   these transitions  over 
a decade of implementing this policy  
have become established in iranian 
urban development literature and have 
shaped the conceptual and operational 
framework of policies  programs  and 
actions 
at the policymaking level  the 
preparation and approval of three 
national strategic documents in 
three consecutive decades each 

sustainable urban regeneration in i r  iran   representing an evolutionary step in 
theoretical and operational dimensions 
compared to its predecessor 
have played a decisive role  the 
establishment of  sustainable urban 
regeneration taskforce  at national  
provincial  and local levels  and the 
shift from purely physical indicators 
to  livability indicators  and  inclusive  
urban indicators in the process of 
identification  revitalization  and 
upgrading  signify a transformation at 
the policy level 
at the planning level  the formulation 
of the  national urban regeneration 
program  and the transformation of 
urban regeneration into a  national 
issue  within the framework of the sixth 
national development plan have been 
important steps in institutionalizing this 
approach in macro development plans 
at the action level  the experience 
of establishing and operating  local 
development institutions  and 
implementing the  joint comprehensive 
plan of action  in both thematic and 
area based categories demonstrates an 
effort to combine institutional  social  and physical capacities with the aim of 
improving urban quality of life within 
the framework of sustainable urban 
regeneration 
despite challenges in the process of 
implementation  institution building  
inter sectoral coordination  and 
resource mobilization  sustainable 
urban regeneration policy in iran has 
generally shown a progressive trend 
and has managed to establish its 
position within iran s urban planning 
and development system  this 
experience  particularly in terms of 
institution building  strengthening local 
participation  enhancing the role of local 
communities in decision making  and 
giving simultaneous attention to social  
economic  physical  and environmental 
dimensions in programs and actions  
has high potential for transfer to other 
countries facing similar conditions 
in conclusion  it can be said that 
sustainable urban regeneration policy 
in iran has not only created a discursive 
shift in the perception of deprived urban 
areas but has also been able to lay 
the foundations for multi level action  

lessons learned   integrated planning  and participatory 
policymaking  based on this experience  
some of the most important extractable 
lessons learned are 
  integrated management and 
program cohesion   effective 
advancement of regeneration programs 
requires integrated management 
at various levels and inter sectoral 
coordination in policy formulation and 
implementation  this is achieved when 
regeneration programs and actions are 
directly linked to comprehensive spatial 
and urban development documents  
and a departure is made from 
uncoordinated sectoral and project 
based approaches 
  attention to the diversity of deprived 
area types   success in regeneration 
necessitates a precise understanding 
of the diversity among deprived urban 
areas  including deteriorated  historic  
and informal settlements  adopting 
differentiated approaches tailored to 
the characteristics of each type of 
these areas significantly increases the 
effectiveness and efficiency of policies 
and executive actions 
  contextualized and inclusive social 
policy   iran s experience shows that 
social policies must be formulated in a way that they are both inclusive of 
different societal strata and appropriate 
to the socio economic characteristics 
of each region  the focus of these 
policies on strengthening the family 
institution through the provision of 
services such as education  health  
housing  insurance  and social support 
plays a fundamental role in enhancing 
urban resilience and social justice 
  housing and urban development 
affordable for low income groups  
reforming urban planning orientations 
and formulating regulations appropriate 
to the economic capacity and living 
conditions of low income groups 
are prerequisites for success in 
regeneration  achieving this goal 
requires a review of the housing and 
urban planning policymaking system 
  gradual upgrading   effective 
regeneration is based on the gradual  
step by step improvement of the 
quality of life in the neighborhood  
this process will be successful when 
intervention measures are designed 
and implemented not from top down 
but based on the capacities  assets  and 
participation of the residents 
  voluntary and safe resettlement 
in the face of hazards   when dealing 
with areas exposed to natural or 

sustainable urban regeneration in i r  iran   man made hazards  the principle of 
resettlement must be accompanied 
by full respect for human rights  active 
participation of residents  ensuring 
social satisfaction  and guaranteeing 
suitable housing replacement  
successful implementation of this 
principle requires effective dialogue and 
fair compensation mechanisms 
  strengthening local management 
and decentralization   increasing 
the authority and capacity of local 
institutions  including municipalities 
and local bodies  plays a pivotal role 
in achieving regeneration  utilizing 
participatory mechanisms  capacity 
building for civil society organizations  
and enhancing the link between people 
and decision making institutions 
are key factors for success in local 
regeneration management 
  targeted support for vulnerable 
groups   policymaking in deprived areas will not be effective without 
identifying and providing special 
support to vulnerable groups  
especially female headed households  
children  the elderly  and persons with 
disabilities  designing empowerment 
and social support programs tailored 
to the conditions of these groups is a 
necessity for equity oriented planning 
  mobilizing endogenous resources 
with external convergence   advancing 
sustainable regeneration policy 
requires the optimal aggregation of 
local  governmental  public  community  
and private resources  appropriate 
institution building and the use of 
innovative financial and institutional 
tools can provide the platform for the 
effective use of neighborhoods  internal 
capacities and create synergy with 
external resources 

lessons learned   glossary of terms
urban regeneration  the process 
of comprehensive development in 
economic  social  environmental and 
physical terms aimed at enhancing 
the quality of life bacross target urban 
areas and neighborhoods in connection 
with the rest of the city

neighborhoods  areas that are 
the subject of regularization plans of 
this document based on approved

rehabilitation and renovation 
deprived urban areas  these 
are areas within the city that require 
revitalisation  upgrading  and 
revitalization  they are categorized 
into types such as historic areas  
deteriorated areas  and informal 
settlements  the prominent 
characteristics of these areas are as 
follows 
  residents have lower per capita 
incomes and higher unemployment 
rates as compared with the city 
averages 
  as compared with the city averages  
housing units are not durable  
population density is high  and there are also environmental problems 
  residents have inadequate access to 
urban services and infrastructure 
  as compared with the rest of the city  
social aberrations are apparent and 
further encouraged 
  historic and cultural identities have 
been neglected social dignity and 
social esteem have declined in these 
areas giving rise to an underclass 
substitution effect
deteriorated urban area   refers 
to areas within a city where  over past 
years  constituent elements including 
superstructures  infrastructure  
buildings  structures  streets  and 
access ways have become dilapidated 
and inefficient  and whose residents 
suffer from multiple economic  social  
cultural  and physical problems

city reflecting cultural historic values

by apparent characteristics and 
constituent structures 
informal settlement   areas

migrants and the urban poor  which 
have developed without legal permits 
and outside of formal and legal urban 
development planning  such as 
comprehensive and detailed plans   
either within or outside the legal 
boundaries of cities

residents  assets and capabilities with 
the aim of enhancing their own quality 
of life and enabling their participation 
in the regularization and development 
process

to a set of systematic policies  
programmes  and actions within various 
spatial  social  land  and housing

preventing the formation and growth of

urban areas and neighborhoods 
through reanimation  revitalization  
rehabilitation and renovation that 
enable residents and enhance the 
quality of their lives and activities in the 
settlements

economic  socio cultural and physical 
terms  aimed at restoring proper living conditions based on new relations 
and establishing a dynamic balance in 
target urban areas and neighborhoods 
revitalization  the purposive 
process comprising a set of measures

the quality of target zones and 
neighborhoods while preserving their 
authenticity and integrity

approach to improving the physical  
social  economic and environmental 
conditions of deprived urban areas

improvements  and institutional 
development  with community

اصول اخالقی طرح : 
4-  ما تالش می کنیم در ابتدا  نگاه خودمان را عوض کنیم و واقعاً بر مبنایموازین و مدل اسالمی عمل کنیم . 
و معتقدیم این نگاه منشاء خیر و برکت خواهد شد. به دنبال این نگاه ، نگرش و خیاالت مردم محله ارتقاء 
می دهیم. 
2-  هدفمان ساده ، روشن و عملیاتیاست و از طریق خود افراد محله قابل انجام است. تحول محله از خود آدم 
های آن محله شکل می گیرد. 
3- .ارتقای هویت ، افزایش رفاه و مقتدرسازی جوانان محله واژه های کلیدی و زیربنایی کار ما خواهد بود 
1-  ما از ویژگی های مثبت محله به عنوان نقاط قوت استفاده کنیم و از طریق نقطه قوت آنها نیازهای محله را
تامین خواهیم کرد.  
5- حمایت ما از خانواده ها غیرملموس و غیر مستقیم و از تشویق نقاط قوت و برجسته جوانان  تا 34  سال آنان
خواهد بود و بدون جدایی از پدر و مادر آنها آسیب آنها را برطرف سازیم. 
6-  ما نه بر مبنای ترحم  بلکه مهرورزی و احسان به بندگان خدا به صورت چهره به چهره با آنها مواجه می
شویم و از طریق خودشان تغییر ایجاد می کنیم و هیچ کس را خارج از محل نمی آوریم.  
7-  با معتادین محله به عنوان بیماران نیازمند درمان و دارای کرامت و عزت مواجه خواهیم شد وجداگانه با آنها
کار می کنیم. 
8-  آگاهی بخش و ارتقای سطح بینشی و تحصیالتی جوانان و بچه ها  از برنامه های اساسی ما در قالب فرایندی

های آن محله شکل می‌گیرد. 
۳ -. ارتقای هویت، افزایش رفاه و مقتدرسازی جوانان محله واژه‌های کلیدی و زیربنایی کار ما خواهد بود
۱ - ما از ویژگی‌های مثبت محله به عنوان نقاط قوت استفاده کنیم و از طریق نقطه قوت آنها نیازهای محله را
تامین خواهیم کرد. 
۵ - حمایت ما از خانواده‌ها غیرملموس و غیر مستقیم و از تشویق نقاط قوت و برجسته جوانان تا ۳۴ سال آنان
خواهد بود و بدون جدایی از پدر و مادر آنها آسیب آنها را برطرف سازیم. 
۶ - ما نه بر مبنای ترحم بلکه مهرورزی و احسان به بندگان خدا به صورت چهره به چهره با آنها مواجه می
شویم و از طریق خودشان تغییر ایجاد می‌کنیم و هیچ‌کس را خارج از محل نمی‌آوریم. 
۷ - با معتادین محله به عنوان بیماران نیازمند درمان و دارای کرامت و عزت مواجه خواهیم شد وجداگانه با آنها
کار می‌کنیم. 
۸ - آگاهی‌بخش و ارتقای سطح بینشی و تحصیالتی جوانان و بچه‌ها از برنامه‌های اساسی ما در قالب فرایندی
نرم بوده و در این فرآیند از اعمال قدرت و پول پاشی و توزیع رانت دوری می‌کنیم. 
۹ -. در جهت احیا و برجسته‌سازی شخصیت‌های اسطوره‌ای محله سعی وافر خواهیم نمود
۴۴ - در جهت ارتقای تدریجی هویت محله و ساکنان آن مسئولیت‌ها را به اجزاء کوچکتر خرد نموده و به
جوانان محله واگذار می‌کنیم. 
۴۴ - پذیرش فرماندهی واحد برای ایفای مسئولیت‌های مختلف و پیشبرد کارها با هم برای ما یک اصل اساسی
است. خدمات ما بدون تبعیض برای همه واجدان شرایط محله از یک پنجره واحد ارایه خواهد شد. 

دبیرخانهطرح توسعه و تحول اجتماع محور محالت کم برخوردار
۳
: مقدمه
در فرآیند کنونی برنامه‌ریزی و مدیریت توسعه شهری، استفاده از راهبردهای مشارکتی و رویکرد برنامه ر یزی از
پایین به باال به تدریج مورد اجماع برنامه ریزان قرار گرفته است. تحقق این رویکرد، نیازمند تعریف نظام تقسیمات
فضایی خردتری است که میتوان «محله» را به عنوان واحد پایه و محور برنامه‌ریزی مشارکتی در عرصه همگانی
در شهرهای قلمداد کرد. 
به دلیل وجود معضالتی چون افزایش نابهنجاریهای اجتماعی، کمرنگ شدن هویت و حس تعلق اجتماعی، 
افزایش مشکالت اکولوژی، اجتماعی و محیطی، نابرابریهای شگرف اجتماعی – اقتصادی و در مجموع کاهش
کیفیت زندگی، تمام تالشها معطوف به استفاده از رویکرد راهبرد مشارکتی شد ه است که رهیافتهای حاکم
بر آن را میتوان در دو قالب فکری کالن و خرد تبیین کرد: 
الف- مدیریت متمرکز، اقتدارگرا در سطح کالن یا به تعبیری از باال به پایین
ب- مشارکت جمعی، بسیج اجتماعی، برنامه‌ریزی مشارکتی یا از پایین به باال
دیدگاه دوم می‌توان منجر به کشف و ایجاد ظرفیت‌های نهادی، تقویت اجتماعات محلی، توسعه مدیریت
راهبردی – مشارکتی، بسیج منابع انسانی و تمرکز زدایی گردد، که در نهایت اعتالی مدیریت و برنامه‌ریزی شهری
را سبب می‌شود. 










دبیرخانهطرح توسعه و تحول اجتماع محور محالت کم برخوردار
۴
روش احیاء ظرفیت‌های محلیدر راستای توانمند سازی محالت کم برخوردار: 
محله، محدودهای شهری با ترکیب متوازنی از فعالیت‌های انسانی، که اطراف مرکز معین و مشخصی ساخته‌شده
است و بعنوان خردترین واحد در نظام برنامه‌ریزی شهری محسوب می‌شود و کانون کنش و
واکنشهای اجتماعی است. 
در تعریف و تبیین مفهوم محله در شهرهای ایران این واژه را میتوان از دو منظر تاریخی و قانونی مورد بررسی
قرار داد. در برداشت تاریخی خصوصیات غالب شهرهای اسالمی در ساختار کالبدی و اجتماعی شهرها به واسطه
تأثیر پذیری از هویت ایرانی – اسالمی نمود بارزی داشته است، به گونه‌ای که محله به عنوان یکی از اجزا و
عناصر شهر ایرانی – اسالمی و تشکیل‌دهنده ساختار و استخوان‌بندی شهرها تلقی می‌شود و محدوده آن نی ز به
واسطه وابستگیهای قومی، نژادی و مذهبی و حرفه‌ای و طبقاتی تعریف شدنی است. این برداشت در گذر زمان
دچار تغییر و تحوالتی شد، به گونه‌ای که در نظام شهر نشینی و شهرسازی کشور محله‌های سنتی کمت ر به مصداق
گذشته و با کارکردهای قابل انتظار از آنها وجود دارد. در برداشت حقوقی و قانونی، بررسی قوانین فعلی نشان
می‌دهد مهم‌ترین قانونی که محله در آن تعریف‌شده است، تبصره ۲ ماده ۱ قانونتقسیمات کشوری مصوب
۴۳۶۲ است که محله را مجموعه‌ای از ساختمانهای مسکونی و خدماتی بیان می‌کند، که از لحاظ بافت اجتماعی
ساکنان خود را اهل آن می‌دانند و دارای محدوده معین است. حدود محله‌های شهری تابع تقسیمات شهری است. 
در شهرهای بزرگ از به هم پیوستن چند محله شهری، منط قه شهری تشکیل می‌شود. 
در مطالعه و شناخت محله باید به چهار عامل توجه داشت: 
۴ - مرزهای کالبدی و نمادی
۲ - پیوندهای اجتماعی
۳ - تسهیالت و خدمات محلی
۱ - هویتو احساس تعلق نسبت به مکان زندگی






دبیرخانهطرح توسعه و تحول اجتماع محور محالت کم برخوردار
۵
: ساختار عملیاتی طرح
بر اساس مطالعات انجام پذیرفته‌شده به منظور افزایش مشارکت عمومی و احیاء ظرفیت‌های کالبدی، اقتصادی، 
اجتماعی، زیست‌محیطی و فرهنگی محله، محور برنامه‌ریزی در این طرح، محله تعریف گردید، جهت
احصاء و هماهنگی ظرفیت‌های محلی در سطح محالت، خانه راه‌اندازی می‌شود، محدوده جغرافیایی خانه منطبق
بر محدوده جغرافیایی محله می‌باشد. 
خانه محل تجمیع همه دستگاه‌های خدمات رسان در محله می‌باشد و مسئول خانه، مسئولیت هماهنگی بین بخشی
دستگاه‌ها، سازمان‌ها و تشکل‌ها را در سطح محله برعهده دارد. 
طبق مطالعات انجام پذیرفته‌شده بر اساس شاخص‌های توسعه‌یافتگی مجموعا ۰۲۰۲ محله کم برخوردار در سطح
کشور موجود می‌باشد که جهت رفع مشکالت و توانمند سازی آنها نیازمند تداخل همزمان چند دستگاه و سازمان
ضروری می‌باشد. 
خانه: محدوه جغرافیایی با متغیرهای اجتماعی، فرهنگی، اقتصادی و اکولوژیکی ویژه که بر گرفته از مفهوم محله
می‌باشد. 
مسئول خانه: مسئول خانه یکی از ساکنین معتمد محله می‌باشد، که توسط یک دستگاه یا نهاد یا سازمان
انتخاب و مسئولیت هماهنگی خانه را بر عهده می‌گیرد. 
محله کم برخوردار: محله است که از نظر شاخص‌های توسعه‌یافتگی در حد ضعیف می‌باشد و تجمیع
آسیب‌های اجتماعی در این محالت مشاهده می‌شود، به گونه‌ای که یک دستگاه یا نهاد یا سازمان، قادر به
حل مشکالت محله نمی‌باشد و ضرورت تداخل همزمان چند دستگاه یا سازمان یا نهاد وجود دارد. 
پهنه بندی: جهت مدیریت بر محالت کم برخوردار، محله را به واحدهای کوچک قابل مدیریت تقسیم می
نماییم، به این واحدها، پهنه اطالق می‌شود، مجموعه پهنه‌ها، محله کم برخوردار را تشکیل می‌دهد. 
مسئول پهنه: یکی از ساکنین و از معتمدان پهنه می‌باشد، هماهنگی عملیات اجرایی در پهنه توسط مسئول پهنه
انجام می‌پذیرد. 
پهنه بندی محالت با کمک گرفتن از اطالعات جمعیت (تعداد جمعیت، خانوار، سرانه و …) و نقشه‌های شهرسازی
، حمل و نقل، فضای سبز، نقشه‌های خدماتی محله (فرهنگی، آموزشی، ورزشی و …) انجام می‌گیرد. 
محدوده فعالیت شهردار کوچه: کوچک‌ترین واحد مدیریت در سطح محله کم برخوردار با حدود
جغرافیایی خاص و قابل تعریف. 
شهردار کوچه: شخصی است که دارای سه شاخص (مقبولیت، ساکن کوچه بودن و دارای سن زیر ۰۲) سال
می‌باشد. 
دبیرخانه: مرکز هدایت، هماهنگی، پایش، ارزیابی و نظارت خانه‌ها در محالت کم برخوردار می‌باشد.

دبیرخانهطرح توسعه و تحول اجتماع محور محالت کم برخوردار
۷
نقش و وظایف دستگاه‌ها، سازمان‌ها و نهادها
۱ -: هالل احمر راه‌اندازی خانه هالل، برگزاری دوره‌های آموزش کمک‌های اولیه، امداد و نجات و
…، تامین دارو نیازمندان و همکاری در طرح غربالگری و پزشک خانواده
۰ -:) کمیته امداد امام خمینی (ره ساماندهی خیرین محله و راه‌اندازی مراکز نیکوکاری، ساماندهی
و حمایت از زنان سرپرست خانوار، ایتام، خانواده‌های زندانیان، و خانواده‌های معتادان در حال ترک و
سرپرستان از کار افتاده، اشتغال‌زایی و پرداخت تسهیالت کم‌بهره و توزیع اقالم اساسی نیازمندان
۰ -: سازمان بهزیستی راه‌اندازی مراکز مثبت زندگی مبتنی به ظرفیت‌های محلی، ساماندهی و حمایت
از معلولین و آسیب‌دیده‌های اجتماعی و کودکان کار، همکاری در راستای ساماندهی معتادان محله، 
همکاری در جهت ساماندهی فعالیت‌های تشکل‌ها و سازمان‌های مردم نهاد محله
۴ - ستاد اجرایی فرمان امام خمینی (ره) و بنیاد احسان، بنیاد مستضعفان: حمایت و پشتیبانی از
فعالیت‌های تشکل‌ها، مساجد و گروه‌های مردمی و جهادی محله، توزیع ارزاق اساسی، حمایت و
پشتیبانی از حوزه ورزش حرفه‌ای، ساماندهی گروه‌های جهادی و پشتیبانی جهت احداث، بازسازی و
ترمیم منازل ومدارس و سایر اماکن فرهنگی و مذهبی محله و مشارکت در حوزه بهداشت و درمان محله
۵ -: آموزش و پرورش راه‌اندازی شورای مدیران مدارس در محله، برنامه‌ریزی و ساماندهی ادامه
تحصیل کودکان بازمانده از تحصیل در محله، کمک به راه‌اندازی مرکزنوآوری دانش آموزی، تدوین
برنامه ارتقاء سطح آموزشی و تحصیلی دانش آموزان، احداث، نوسازی و بازسازی و ترمیم مدارس
۶ -: شهرداری تدوین طرح و ساماندهی بافت‌های فرسوده محله و صدور مجوز احداث، نوسازی و ترمیم
منازل مسکونی، اصناف و سایر اماکن عمومی محله، اجرای طرح کاداست در محله با همکاری اداره
ثبت امالک، احداث و توسعه فضای سبز و سایر اماکن فرهنگی، آموزشی، ورزشی و تفریحی محله، 
ساماندهی گاراژهای بازیافتی، تدوین طرح ارتقاء خدمات شهری محله (جمع‌آوری زباله، رفت و روب، 
روشنایی، آسفالت، نزوالت جوی و آبهای سطحی و …) 
۷ -: صندوق کارآفرینی برگزاری دوره آموزشی ایجاد و ارتقاء کسب و کارهای محلی، راه‌اندازی
صندوق‌های خرد محلی و پرداخت تسهیالت کم‌بهره، پایش و ارزیابی کسب و کارهای محله
۸ - وزارت تعاون، کار و رفاه اجتماعی و اتاق تعاون ایران و استانها: برگزاری دوره‌های آموزشی
و ساماندهی و راه‌اندازی تعاونی توسعه محله

دبیرخانهطرح توسعه و تحول اجتماع محور محالت کم برخوردار
۸
۹ -: صدا و سیما استعدادیابی و برگزاری دوره‌های آموزشی فیلم‌برداری، عکاسی، خبرنگاری، بازیگری
، موسیقی و …، تهیه ارشیو اقدامات در سطح خانه‌ها، تهیه مستند‌های از اقدامات در سطح خانه‌ها، تهیه
برنامه‌های تخصصی و مناسبتی در سطح خانه‌ها
۱۲ -: شرکت بازآفرینی ایران و سازمان نوسازی مطالعات محالت فرسوده کم برخوردار و تهیه طرح
عملیاتی و بسته‌های سرمایه گذاری و همکاری و پشتیبانی اجرا
۱۱ - معاونت علمی و فناوری رئیس‌جمهور و مراکز دانشگاهی: راه‌اندازی مراکزنوآوری با
محوریت استارت آپ‌های دانش آموزی و کارخانه نوآوری در حوزه کسب و کار، کمک به تجهیز
حوزه فناوری و اطالعات مدارس
۱۰ - سازمان اوقاف و امور خیریه: همکاری در جهت نوسازی و ترمیم مراکز آموزشی، فرهنگی و
مذهبی اموال اوقافی در سطح محالت کم برخوردار، شناسایی اموال موقوفه در سطح محالت کم
برخوردار و واگذاری بهره‌برداری ان به مسئولین خانه‌ها بعنوان امین موقوفه جهت راه‌اندازی کسب و
کارهای محلی
۱۰ - سازمانفنی و حرفه‌ای: تدوین برنامه و برگزاری دوره‌های آموزش مهارتی در سطح محالت کم
برخوردار در راستای نیازهای محله جهت اشتغال با اولویت جوانان جویای کار
۱۴ -: بسیج همکاری حوزه‌ها و پایگاه‌های بسیج جهت مشارکت در راه‌اندازی طرح شهرداران کوچه، 
همکاری و مشارکت در طرح‌های عمرانی، فرهنگی، ورزشی و مناسبت‌های مذهبی
۱۵ - شبکه بهداشت و دانشگاه‌های علوم پزشکی: طرح غربال‌گری، اجرای طرح پزشک خانواده و
همکاری در کلیه‌های حوزه‌های مرتبط با بهداشت و درمان محالت کم برخوردار
۱۱ - بکارگیری سایر دستگاه‌ها و نهادها بر حسب تشخیص استانداران محترم (بر اساس
ظرفیت‌های محلی)
